message: Sweet service!
Thanks @jonas3d! Always glad to hear someone else digs it.

@zac @johnegan Great job, guys! I just tried a number of different scenarios, and it "just worked." Sendoid presents a fairly elegant solution to a persistent issue, and its definitely going on the toolbelt for regular use :)

I really like the concept. Simple and to the point. I just wish this could be done without an app or, even better, without Flash (although I realize it is pretty key to your whole p2p implementation).

hi
can I share file with more then 1 user ?
you can share to more than one person! the meshing like bit torrent will be available shortly, I'm working on implementing it now
Also I really appreciate everyone who took the time to come and ask questions, Its been a really long day for us and its nice to know people care about the service that we've put so much time into
Hi, does Sendoid need some unusual port open to work?
I can't connect with either the web app or the installed app. Do I need to do something speical?
I also cannot connect, even machine to machine on my LAN. How can I troubleshoot?

If you guys can go to cc.rtmfp.net and take a screenshot and email it to us at feedback@sendoid.com it would be great. The issue is most likely network configuration preventing the peer negotiation. If we can't fix it immediately the meshing stuff we are working on should hopefully solve it for most of you.
The problem is usually because both parties are behind a symmetric NAT, multiple DHCP gateways.

I would love an android app, the browser-based interface works but is clunky for mobile. It should be (relatively) easy for android since we have the air runtime. Also I would love if it could do a permanent link between 2 machines (ie my pc and phone) so that it could automatically transfer things without needing to go to the url. This would need password protection and such, but it would be a fantastic service.

I'm actually working on mobile apps next. Android first then iOS. We plan on setting up a "send me a file" kind of method where you can setup a "drop box" where people can send you files instead of the other way around.
You can't connect only if you have a router that doesn't preserve the public UDP port.
i made some testing with 3 routers(cisco,zyxel,speedtouch) , only the speedtouch didn't work

the problem is that for doing fast data transfer, UDP protocol is used , and the preservetion of UDP port is not a standard for all manufactures. i'm talking about when you have a router with NAT. that  is not the problem with TCP protocol. If data transfer would be made with TCP it would be no problem. So the conclusion is that it depends on how your router is doing NAT translations for UDP
yeah like @mitza_cz stated, one possible issue is a router doing "symmetric NAT" which doesn't preserve UDP points, this breaks the NAT hole punching technology we use

With the p2p download, does it pull from the other downloaders like the usual p2p usages like bit torrent.  I can see a system like this coming in handy with site's that have a lot of downloads happening at the same time.
It does not yet @jonas3d. Though we have written the technology to do so. I'm working on implementing it in a manner that still provides control for the original sender.
@zac ok sweet!  Looking forward to seeing what you have up your sleeve.
Will you solve the problem with "symetric NAT"?

its impossible to solve because of the way symmetric NATs function, they don't preserve the UDP port so its impossible to accomplish UDP hole punching through them, but I'm hoping to work around the problem, in LAN situations, with a serverless self detecting kind of system, and in WAN situations with the meshing technology
need to fix the server's link generation code first though because all you guys are using up all my database entires and making the links take forever to popout cause IM A LAZY PROGRAMMER

Assuming the file size is within the limits of their hardware, your receivers shouldn't need to download anything to receive a file.
Yes it should work through a Linksys WRT54GS. Its actually what I have at home. No ports should need to be forwarded.

Hi there: for all of you on here who have tried using Sendoid but can't get any files to transfer, I think I have found a simple workaround that is easy to apply and it seems to work - at least for me and does not involve anything complicated like port forwarding. Try this: take the internet "in-cable" that goes into your wifi router and plug it straight into your laptop - don't make a wired connection to your wifi router - I mean take the main internet cable that goes into your router and plug it straight into your computer instead. If you do that then you bypass your router completely and, in geek terminology, you don't have synchronous NAT. It worked for me. It does of course mean that no-one else on your network can use the internet while you are downloading but it is only for a few minutes because the file transfer is so fast.
